Increasing the probability for my "yes" forecast slightly because of the Jan. 5 NYT article about how PG&E has spent $8.4 million in 2018 to lobby Sacramento to seek a solution to avoid bankruptcy.  The article presented these lobbying efforts in a negative light, which may influence lawmakers to avoid accommodating the company.   https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/05/business/energy-environment/california-wildfire-electric.html  "Consumer Watchdog, for example, found that PG&E and the other two utilities had contributed to the campaigns of between 80 percent and 90 percent of state legislators over the last two years."  This is not a good article in terms of the optics of PG&E getting a bailout from Sacramento.   Jamie Court, president of Consumer Watchdog, is vocal in his opposition to a bailout for utility companies.  “They socialize the risk and privatize the profits,” he has said. The correct answer for this question is probably "no", but I'm leaning toward "yes" because of the company's announcement on January 4 that it is exploring a bankruptcy filing and because of the large numbers involved (an additional $15 billion according to Citigroup; PG&E's shareholder equity is only $19.4 billion according to YCharts https://ycharts.com/companies/PCG/shareholders_equity).  The NYT article bolsters this scenario.  PG&E said its liability insurance for the year that began Aug. 1 amounted to $1.4 billion. The primary reason the correct answer could be "no" is SB 901:  "Some analysts say California’s regulators and lawmakers could take steps to extend similar protection in this year’s blazes.  'It is our expectation that regulators will utilize the tools or framework outlined in S.B. 901 to address any potential 2018 wildfire-related costs,' Jeffrey Cassella, an analyst at Moody’s Investors Service, wrote in an email.   Under the bill, utilities could sell bonds to cover their liability costs and pay them off over time through higher rates.  PG&E estimates that the cost to the average consumer could be $5 a year for every $1 billion in bonds issued." https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/14/business/energy-environment/california-fire-utilities.html?module=inline

Talking on bankruptcy has been out for few months now. Options:
- Chapter 11 protection to continue activities as debtor in possession. 
- It was already done in 2001 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Gas_and_Electric_Company) with a cost of $10B and higher prices for their customers for several years. Not good for management.
- Threats of bankruptcy as way to put more pressure in California State.
- But, could also trigger and accelerate suits before filling for Chapter 11.

The company reported Friday Jan. 4 that it is exploring filing for bankruptcy.  Shares of PG&E, which has a market capitalization of $12.7 billion, dropped 24 percent in after hours trading in New York on Friday, on the news.  It has reportedly drawn down $3 billion from its credit lines to bolster its cash reserves, a move common to companies in financial distress.  Since it filed for bankruptcy in 2001, there is clear precedent for it to do so.   Pacific Gas and Electric could ultimately have to pay homeowners and others an estimated $30 billion for causing fires over the last two years. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/05/business/energy-environment/california-wildfire-electric.html  So we have a company that seems likely to have responsibility for billions in damages, being sued by insurers and consumers, making moves common to companies in financial distress, and making an announcement that it is in fact exploring filing for bankruptcy, a move frequently made by companies in distress and one that it has done before.  It seems shortsighted to not at least give this a 50/50 chance of happening.
